{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3670229,"name":"Itay Kaufman","username":"ItayKauf","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/itaykauf/{size}/264000_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-30T14:43:45.004Z","cooked":"

We are looking to add a 4th axis to our CNC router for manufacturing profiles on one go instead of running it 4 times for 4 diffrent planes. Has anyone looked at the idea or has insights about if it’s worth it? We are also intrested in learning about more uses for a 4th axis. Thanks in advance!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-06-30T14:45:11.822Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":26,"reads":359,"readers_count":358,"score":231.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":503773,"topic_slug":"purchasing-a-4-axis-attachment-for-a-cnc","display_username":"Itay Kaufman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60124,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4590 GreenBlitz Team Captain "},"post_url":"/t/purchasing-a-4-axis-attachment-for-a-cnc/503773/1","custom_user_title":"4590 GreenBlitz Team Captain ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3670244,"name":"Chadfrom7226","username":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-30T14:58:43.869Z","cooked":"

I’ve used one before on a tormach. It’s cool but it’s a bit of a pain to use. If you are doing tubes, the long tubes will chatter a lot especially if unsupported on one end. If you support the other end, it is a pain to set up and tear down

What we’re going to do with our new router table is make a fixture that has 1” and 2” side holders. Then you can make a hard stop and a nice feature to zero off of so you don’t have to touch off tools/find origin again as long as you don’t move the fixture

If you end up getting your 4th axis for your router, let me know how it works for you!

For tubes we use a 2 Flute Helical Reduced Neck end mill so you can do both sides in one setup, they are kind of expensive. If you had a a surface grinder and a 5C indexing jig you could make them Reduced Neck End Mills

I have a PocketNC and even the 5th axis is huge. I didn’t think I would ever use it but once I had it the design ideas just kept coming. We just bought the 4th axis addition for our Carvera because of the handiness of the PocketNC

What sort of parts are you making on the PNC? We have one as well, but have yet to be very impressed by it.

Doing a simple 1x2 tube plug fully took something like 8-12 hours. Instead we’re doing the 2.5D passes on our traditional router CNC and do the finishing pass and the side holes on the PNC.

The PNC is a fairly new tool for my team(got it after the season ended). The very first thing I used it for was to make some round tube plugs so I could swap our cascading elevator to continuous(I can’t find any photos, sorry). It is definitely not the fastest machine, but for one off niche parts like the round tube plugs, it came in super handy.

Another thing I like about the PNC is how small it is. I summer in Maine (I’m from Massachusetts) and I literally just tossed it (and the robot, and a laser cutter, and my 3d printer) in my car and drove up here yesterday. Having a portable reliable 5axis cnc is huge for me at least.
